title: 104_s1789
content: The Act may be cited as the "Prevention of Prisoner Double-Dipping Act" and addresses the treatment of prisoners. The "Prevention of Prisoner Double-Dipping Act" amends the Social Security Act to deny benefits to individuals jailed on felony charges, with exceptions after the first 30 days of confinement. The Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a study on timely reporting of information regarding individuals in jails or prisons under court orders. A report must be submitted within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commissioner of Social Security will submit a report on a study conducted regarding timely reporting of information on individuals in jails or prisons. Amendments made by this subsection will apply to payments after the enactment date. Additionally, the Commissioner is authorized to enter into a contract for implementing the prohibition against payment of benefits to prisoners. The Commissioner is authorized to enter into a contract with State or local institutions to provide necessary information on confined individuals for benefit purposes. The Commissioner can enter into contracts with State or local institutions to obtain inmate information for benefit purposes, with the amount determined by the Commissioner. Section 552a of title 5, United States Code, does not apply to these contracts. The Commissioner is authorized to pay institutions for inmates eligible for benefits under this title, who become ineligible due to certain circumstances. Section 552a of title 5, United States Code, does not apply to contracts or information exchanged for benefit purposes. Civil monetary penalties for fraudulent use of Social Security account numbers and cards are outlined in Section 3. The amendment to section 1129 of the Social Security Act outlines penalties for fraudulent use of social security account numbers and cards, including using false information, altering cards, buying or selling cards, and possessing counterfeit cards with intent to sell or alter. The amendment to the Social Security Act imposes civil money penalties of up to $5,000 for disclosing social security account numbers unlawfully. Additionally, violators may face an assessment of up to 5 times the benefits paid under titles II and XVI. The amendment also amends section 1129(c) by replacing "statements and representations" with "actions". These changes apply to conduct occurring after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 authorizes $50,000,000 for the Commissioner of Social Security to combat fraud by increasing investigators and auditors. This funding is in addition to any other appropriations. The Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a study to streamline the review and appeals process under the Social Security Act. A report on the study results must be submitted to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee within 1 year of the Act's enactment.
